subject: Photography
title: Underwater Photography
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: Underwater Photography.

hook.text: Below the surface, light behaves differently. Colors disappear. Everything floats. It's photography on another planet.

buildup.text: Water absorbs red light first. By ten meters deep, everything looks blue-green unless you add artificial light.

discovery.text: Underwater photographers use strobes to restore color and housings to protect cameras from crushing pressure.

twist.text: Buoyancy makes composition hard. You're floating, your subject is moving, and currents push you off position.

climax.text: The best underwater images show a world most people will never visit â€” alien, beautiful, and fragile.

punchline.text: Underwater, you're a visitor in someone else's world.

quiz.question: Why does everything look blue-green underwater?
options: Water absorbs red light first, leaving blue-green tones
